an10.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an10.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an10.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.1:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an10.1:2.1.eng: “Sir, what is the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics?”

an10.1:2.2.eng: “Ānanda, having no regrets is the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics.”

an10.1:3.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of having no regrets?”

an10.1:3.2.eng: “Joy is the purpose and benefit of having no regrets.”

an10.1:4.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of joy?”

an10.1:5.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of rapture?”

an10.1:6.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of tranquility?”

an10.1:7.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of bliss?”

an10.1:8.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of immersion?”

an10.1:9.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing?”

an10.1:10.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment and dispassion?”

an10.1:10.2.eng: “Knowledge and vision of freedom is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment and dispassion.

an10.1:11.1.pli: Iti kho, ānanda, kusalāni sīlāni avippaṭisāratthāni avippaṭisārānisaṃsāni;
an10.1:11.1.eng: So, Ānanda, the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics is not having regrets.

an10.1:11.2.eng: Joy is the purpose and benefit of not having regrets.

an10.1:11.3.eng: Rapture is the purpose and benefit of joy.

an10.1:11.4.eng: Tranquility is the purpose and benefit of rapture.

an10.1:11.5.eng: Bliss is the purpose and benefit of tranquility.

an10.1:11.6.eng: Immersion is the purpose and benefit of bliss.

an10.1:11.7.eng: Truly knowing and seeing is the purpose and benefit of immersion.

an10.1:11.8.eng: Disillusionment and dispassion is the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing.

an10.1:11.9.eng: Knowledge and vision of freedom is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment and dispassion.

an10.1:11.10.pli: Iti kho, ānanda, kusalāni sīlāni anupubbena aggāya parentī”ti.
an10.1:11.10.eng: So, Ānanda, skillful ethics progressively lead up to the highest.”

an10.10:0.3.eng: Inspiring All Around: the Three Knowledges

an10.10:1.1.pli: “Saddho ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu hoti, no ca sīlavā.
an10.10:1.1.eng: “A mendicant is faithful, but not ethical.

an10.10:1.2.eng: So they’re incomplete in that respect,

an10.10:1.4.eng: ‘How can I become faithful and ethical?’

an10.10:1.5.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddho ca hoti, sīlavā ca, evaṃ so tenaṅgena paripūro hoti.
an10.10:1.5.eng: When the mendicant is faithful and ethical, they’re complete in that respect.

an10.10:2.1.pli: Saddho ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu hoti sīlavā ca, no ca bahussuto bahussuto ca,
an10.10:2.1.eng: A mendicant is faithful and ethical, but not learned …

an10.10:2.3.pli: dhammakathiko ca, no ca parisāvacaro parisāvacaro ca,

an10.10:2.4.pli: no ca visārado parisāya dhammaṃ deseti visārado ca parisāya dhammaṃ deseti,
an10.10:2.4.eng: they don’t teach Dhamma to the assembly with assurance …

an10.10:2.5.eng: they’re not an expert in the monastic law …

an10.10:2.6.pli: no ca anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Anekavihitañca …pe… pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati,
an10.10:2.6.eng: they don’t recollect their many kinds of past lives …

an10.10:2.7.pli: no ca dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti dibbena ca cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe…
an10.10:2.7.eng: they don’t, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, see sentient beings passing away and being reborn …

an10.10:2.8.pli: yathākammūpage satte pajānāti, no ca āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an10.10:2.8.eng: they don’t realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an10.10:2.9.eng: So they’re incomplete in that respect,

an10.10:2.11.pli: ‘kintāhaṃ saddho ca assaṃ, sīlavā ca, bahussuto ca, dhammakathiko ca, parisāvacaro ca, visārado ca parisāya dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, vinayadharo ca, anekavihitañca pubbenivāsaṃ anussareyyaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussareyyaṃ, dibbena ca cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajāneyyaṃ, āsavānañca khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an10.10:2.11.eng: ‘How can I become faithful, ethical, and learned, a Dhamma speaker, one who frequents assemblies, one who teaches Dhamma to the assembly with assurance, an expert in the training, one who recollects their many kinds of past lives, one who with clairvoyance that surpasses the human sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn, and one who lives having realized the ending of defilements?’

an10.10:3.1.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddho ca hoti, sīlavā ca, bahussuto ca, dhammakathiko ca, parisāvacaro ca, visārado ca parisāya dhammaṃ deseti, vinayadharo ca, anekavihitañca pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, dibbena ca cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an10.10:3.1.eng: When they are faithful, ethical, and learned, a Dhamma speaker, one who frequents assemblies, one who teaches Dhamma to the assembly with assurance, an expert in the training, one who recollects their many kinds of past lives, one who with clairvoyance that surpasses the human sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn, and one who lives having realized the ending of defilements,

an10.10:3.3.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu samantapāsādiko ca hoti sabbākāraparipūro cā”ti.
an10.10:3.3.eng: A mendicant who possesses these ten qualities is impressive all around, and is complete in every respect.”

an10.100:1.1.pli: “Dasayime, bhikkhave, dhamme appahāya abhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an10.100:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without giving up ten things you can’t realize perfection.

an10.100:1.3.pli: Rāgaṃ, dosaṃ, mohaṃ, kodhaṃ, upanāhaṃ, makkhaṃ, paḷāsaṃ, issaṃ, macchariyaṃ, mānaṃ—
an10.100:1.3.eng: Greed, hate, delusion, anger, acrimony, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, and conceit.

an10.100:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa dhamme appahāya abhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an10.100:1.4.eng: Without giving up these ten things you can’t realize perfection.

an10.100:2.1.pli: Dasayime, bhikkhave, dhamme pahāya bhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an10.100:2.1.eng: After giving up ten things you can realize perfection.

an10.100:2.3.pli: Rāgaṃ, dosaṃ, mohaṃ, kodhaṃ, upanāhaṃ, makkhaṃ, paḷāsaṃ, issaṃ, macchariyaṃ, mānaṃ—
an10.100:2.3.eng: Greed, hate, delusion, anger, acrimony, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, and conceit.

an10.100:2.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa dhamme pahāya bhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātun”ti.
an10.100:2.4.eng: After giving up these ten things you can realize perfection.”

an10.101:1.1.pli: “Tisso imā, bhikkhave, samaṇasaññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti.
an10.101:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when these three perceptions for ascetics are developed and cultivated they fulfill seven things.

an10.101:1.3.pli: Vevaṇṇiyamhi ajjhupagato, parapaṭibaddhā me jīvikā, añño me ākappo karaṇīyoti—
an10.101:1.3.eng: ‘I have secured freedom from class.’ ‘My livelihood is tied up with others.’ ‘My behavior should be different.’

an10.101:1.4.pli: imā kho, bhikkhave, tisso samaṇasaññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti.
an10.101:1.4.eng: When these three perceptions for ascetics are developed and cultivated they fulfill seven things.

an10.101:2.2.pli: Santatakārī hoti santatavutti sīlesu, anabhijjhālu hoti, abyāpajjo hoti, anatimānī hoti, sikkhākāmo hoti, “idamatthan”tissa hoti jīvitaparikkhāresu, āraddhavīriyo ca viharati.
an10.101:2.2.eng: Their deeds and behavior are always consistent with the precepts. They’re content, kind-hearted, and humble. They want to train. They use the necessities of life after reflecting on their purpose. They’re energetic.

an10.101:2.3.pli: Imā kho, bhikkhave, tisso samaṇasaññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ime satta dhamme paripūrentī”ti.
an10.101:2.3.eng: When those three perceptions for ascetics are developed and cultivated they fulfill these seven things.”

an10.102:1.1.pli: “Sattime, bhikkhave, bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā tisso vijjā paripūrenti.
an10.102:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated they fulfill three knowledges.

an10.102:1.3.pli: Satisambojjhaṅgo, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo, vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, pītisambojjhaṅgo, passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, samādhisambojjhaṅgo, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo—
an10.102:1.3.eng: The awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity.

an10.102:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā tisso vijjā paripūrenti.
an10.102:1.4.eng: When these seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated they fulfill three knowledges.

an10.102:1.6.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati,
an10.102:1.6.eng: It’s when a mendicant recollects their many kinds of past lives.

an10.102:1.7.pli: seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
an10.102:1.7.eng: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

an10.102:1.8.pli: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
an10.102:1.8.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human, they understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

an10.102:1.9.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an10.102:1.10.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā imā tisso vijjā paripūrentī”ti.
an10.102:1.10.eng: When those seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated they fulfill these three knowledges.”

an10.103:1.1.pli: “Micchattaṃ, bhikkhave, āgamma virādhanā hoti, no ārādhanā.
an10.103:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, relying on the wrong way leads to failure, not success.

an10.103:1.2.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, micchattaṃ āgamma virādhanā hoti, no ārādhanā?
an10.103:1.2.eng: And how does relying on the wrong way lead to failure, not success?

an10.103:1.3.pli: Micchādiṭṭhikassa, bhikkhave, micchāsaṅkappo pahoti, micchāsaṅkappassa micchāvācā pahoti, micchāvācassa micchākammanto pahoti, micchākammantassa micchāājīvo pahoti, micchāājīvassa micchāvāyāmo pahoti, micchāvāyāmassa micchāsati pahoti, micchāsatissa micchāsamādhi pahoti, micchāsamādhissa micchāñāṇaṃ pahoti, micchāñāṇissa micchāvimutti pahoti.
an10.103:1.3.eng: Wrong view produces wrong thought. Wrong thought produces wrong speech. Wrong speech produces wrong action. Wrong action produces wrong livelihood. Wrong livelihood produces wrong effort. Wrong effort produces wrong mindfulness. Wrong mindfulness produces wrong immersion. Wrong immersion produces wrong knowledge. Wrong knowledge produces wrong freedom.

an10.103:1.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, micchattaṃ āgamma virādhanā hoti, no ārādhanā.
an10.103:1.4.eng: That’s how relying on the wrong way leads to failure, not success.

an10.103:2.1.pli: Sammattaṃ, bhikkhave, āgamma ārādhanā hoti, no virādhanā.
an10.103:2.1.eng: Relying on the right way leads to success, not failure.

an10.103:2.2.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, sammattaṃ āgamma ārādhanā hoti, no virādhanā?
an10.103:2.2.eng: And how does relying on the right way lead to success, not failure?

an10.103:2.3.pli: Sammādiṭṭhikassa, bhikkhave, sammāsaṅkappo pahoti, sammāsaṅkappassa sammāvācā pahoti, sammāvācassa sammākammanto pahoti, sammākammantassa sammāājīvo pahoti, sammāājīvassa sammāvāyāmo pahoti, sammāvāyāmassa sammāsati pahoti, sammāsatissa sammāsamādhi pahoti, sammāsamādhissa sammāñāṇaṃ pahoti, sammāñāṇissa sammāvimutti pahoti.
an10.103:2.3.eng: Right view produces right thought. Right thought produces right speech. Right speech produces right action. Right action produces right livelihood. Right livelihood produces right effort. Right effort produces right mindfulness. Right mindfulness produces right immersion. Right immersion produces right knowledge. Right knowledge produces right freedom.

an10.103:2.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sammattaṃ āgamma ārādhanā hoti, no virādhanā”ti.
an10.103:2.4.eng: That’s how relying on the right way leads to success, not failure.”

an10.104:1.1.pli: “Micchādiṭṭhikassa, bhikkhave, purisapuggalassa micchāsaṅkappassa micchāvācassa micchākammantassa micchāājīvassa micchāvāyāmassa micchāsatissa micchāsamādhissa micchāñāṇissa micchāvimuttissa
an10.104:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, consider an individual who has wrong view, thought, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, immersion, knowledge, and freedom.

an10.104:1.2.pli: yañca kāyakammaṃ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṃ samādinnaṃ yañca vacīkammaṃ yañca manokammaṃ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṃ samādinnaṃ yā ca cetanā yā ca patthanā yo ca paṇidhi ye ca saṅkhārā, sabbe te dhammā aniṭṭhāya akantāya amanāpāya ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattanti.
an10.104:1.2.eng: Whatever bodily, verbal, or mental deeds they undertake in line with that view, their intentions, aims, wishes, and choices all lead to what is unlikable, undesirable, disagreeable, harmful, and suffering.

an10.104:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, nimbabījaṃ vā kosātakibījaṃ vā tittakālābubījaṃ vā allāya pathaviyā nikkhittaṃ yañceva pathavirasaṃ upādiyati yañca āporasaṃ upādiyati, sabbaṃ taṃ tittakattāya kaṭukattāya asātattāya saṃvattati.
an10.104:2.1.eng: Suppose a seed of neem, angled gourd, or bitter gourd was planted in moist earth. Whatever nutrients it takes up from the earth and water would lead to its bitter, acerbic, and unpleasant taste.

an10.104:2.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, micchādiṭṭhikassa purisapuggalassa micchāsaṅkappassa micchāvācassa micchākammantassa micchāājīvassa micchāvāyāmassa micchāsatissa micchāsamādhissa micchāñāṇissa micchāvimuttissa yañceva kāyakammaṃ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṃ samādinnaṃ yañca vacīkammaṃ …
an10.104:2.4.eng: In the same way, consider an individual who has wrong view, thought, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, immersion, knowledge, and freedom.

an10.104:2.5.pli: yañca manokammaṃ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṃ samādinnaṃ yā ca cetanā yā ca patthanā yo ca paṇidhi ye ca saṅkhārā, sabbe te dhammā aniṭṭhāya akantāya amanāpāya ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattanti.
an10.104:2.5.eng: Whatever bodily, verbal, or mental deeds they undertake in line with that view, their intentions, aims, wishes, and choices all lead to what is unlikable, undesirable, disagreeable, harmful, and suffering.

an10.104:3.1.pli: Sammādiṭṭhikassa, bhikkhave, purisapuggalassa sammāsaṅkappassa sammāvācassa sammākammantassa sammāājīvassa sammāvāyāmassa sammāsatissa sammāsamādhissa sammāñāṇissa sammāvimuttissa yañceva kāyakammaṃ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṃ samādinnaṃ yañca vacīkammaṃ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṃ samādinnaṃ yañca manokammaṃ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṃ samādinnaṃ yā ca cetanā yā ca patthanā yo ca paṇidhi ye ca saṅkhārā, sabbe te dhammā iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattanti.
an10.104:3.1.eng: Consider an individual who has right view, thought, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, immersion, knowledge, and freedom. Whatever bodily, verbal, or mental deeds they undertake in line with that view, their intentions, aims, wishes, and choices all lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, beneficial, and pleasant.

an10.104:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ucchubījaṃ vā sālibījaṃ vā muddikābījaṃ vā allāya pathaviyā nikkhittaṃ yañca pathavirasaṃ upādiyati yañca āporasaṃ upādiyati sabbaṃ taṃ sātattāya madhurattāya asecanakattāya saṃvattati.
an10.104:4.1.eng: Suppose a seed of sugar cane, fine rice, or grape was planted in moist earth. Whatever nutrients it takes up from the earth and water would lead to its sweet, pleasant, delectable flavor.

an10.104:4.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhikassa …pe… sammāvimuttissa yañceva kāyakammaṃ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṃ samādinnaṃ yañca vacīkammaṃ …
an10.104:4.4.eng: In the same way, consider an individual who who has right view, thought, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, immersion, knowledge, and freedom.

an10.104:4.5.pli: yañca manokammaṃ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṃ samādinnaṃ yā ca cetanā yā ca patthanā yo ca paṇidhi ye ca saṅkhārā, sabbe te dhammā iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattanti.
an10.104:4.5.eng: Whatever bodily, verbal, or mental deeds they undertake in line with that view, their intentions, aims, wishes, and choices all lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, beneficial, and pleasant.

an10.105:1.1.pli: “Avijjā, bhikkhave, pubbaṅgamā akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā, anvadeva ahirikaṃ anottappaṃ.
an10.105:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, ignorance precedes the attainment of unskillful qualities, with lack of conscience and prudence following along.

an10.105:1.2.pli: Avijjāgatassa, bhikkhave, aviddasuno micchādiṭṭhi pahoti, micchādiṭṭhikassa micchāsaṅkappo pahoti, micchāsaṅkappassa micchāvācā pahoti, micchāvācassa micchākammanto pahoti, micchākammantassa micchāājīvo pahoti, micchāājīvassa micchāvāyāmo pahoti, micchāvāyāmassa micchāsati pahoti, micchāsatissa micchāsamādhi pahoti, micchāsamādhissa micchāñāṇaṃ pahoti, micchāñāṇissa micchāvimutti pahoti.
an10.105:1.2.eng: An ignoramus, sunk in ignorance, produces wrong view. Wrong view produces wrong thought. Wrong thought produces wrong speech. Wrong speech produces wrong action. Wrong action produces wrong livelihood. Wrong livelihood produces wrong effort. Wrong effort produces wrong mindfulness. Wrong mindfulness produces wrong immersion. Wrong immersion produces wrong knowledge. Wrong knowledge produces wrong freedom.

an10.105:2.1.pli: Vijjā, bhikkhave, pubbaṅgamā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā, anvadeva hirottappaṃ.
an10.105:2.1.eng: Knowledge precedes the attainment of skillful qualities, with conscience and prudence following along.

an10.105:2.2.pli: Vijjāgatassa, bhikkhave, viddasuno sammādiṭṭhi pahoti, sammādiṭṭhikassa sammāsaṅkappo pahoti, sammāsaṅkappassa sammāvācā pahoti, sammāvācassa sammākammanto pahoti, sammākammantassa sammāājīvo pahoti, sammāājīvassa sammāvāyāmo pahoti, sammāvāyāmassa sammāsati pahoti, sammāsatissa sammāsamādhi pahoti, sammāsamādhissa sammāñāṇaṃ pahoti, sammāñāṇissa sammāvimutti pahotī”ti.
an10.105:2.2.eng: A sage, firm in knowledge, produces right view. Right view produces right thought. Right thought produces right speech. Right speech produces right action. Right action produces right livelihood. Right livelihood produces right effort. Right effort produces right mindfulness. Right mindfulness produces right immersion. Right immersion produces right knowledge. Right knowledge produces right freedom.”

an10.106:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these ten grounds for wearing away.

an10.106:1.3.eng: For one of right view, wrong view is worn away.

an10.106:1.4.pli: ye ca micchādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti te cassa nijjiṇṇā honti;
an10.106:1.4.eng: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong view are worn away.

an10.106:1.5.pli: sammādiṭṭhipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti.
an10.106:1.5.eng: And because of right view, many skillful qualities are fully developed.

an10.106:2.1.eng: For one of right thought, wrong thought is worn away.

an10.107:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, in the southern lands there is a ceremony named ‘bone-washing’.

an10.107:1.2.pli: Tattha hoti annampi pānampi khajjampi bhojjampi leyyampi peyyampi naccampi gītampi vāditampi.
an10.107:1.2.eng: There they have food, drink, snacks, meals, refreshments, and beverages, as well as dancing, singing, and music.

an10.107:1.3.eng: There is such a washing, I don’t deny it.

an10.107:1.4.pli: Tañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, dhovanaṃ hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati.
an10.107:1.4.eng: But that washing is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

an10.107:2.1.pli: Ahañca kho, bhikkhave, ariyaṃ dhovanaṃ desessāmi, yaṃ dhovanaṃ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati, yaṃ dhovanaṃ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti.
an10.107:2.1.eng: I will teach a noble washing that leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. Relying on that washing, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things.

an10.107:2.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an10.107:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an10.107:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an10.107:3.1.pli: “Katamañca taṃ, bhikkhave, ariyaṃ dhovanaṃ, yaṃ dhovanaṃ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati, yaṃ dhovanaṃ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti?

an10.107:4.1.eng: For one of right view, wrong view is washed away.

an10.107:4.2.pli: ye ca micchādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti te cassa niddhotā honti;
an10.107:4.2.eng: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong view are washed away.

an10.107:4.3.pli: sammādiṭṭhipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti.
an10.107:4.3.eng: And because of right view, many skillful qualities are fully developed.

an10.107:5.1.eng: For one of right thought, wrong thought is washed away. …

an10.107:5.2.eng: For one of right speech, wrong speech is washed away. …

an10.107:5.3.eng: For one of right action, wrong action is washed away. …

an10.107:5.4.eng: For one of right livelihood, wrong livelihood is washed away. …

an10.107:5.5.eng: For one of right effort, wrong effort is washed away. …

an10.107:5.6.eng: For one of right mindfulness, wrong mindfulness is washed away. …

an10.107:5.7.eng: For one of right immersion, wrong immersion is washed away. …

an10.107:5.8.eng: For one of right knowledge, wrong knowledge is washed away. …

an10.107:6.1.eng: For one of right freedom, wrong freedom is washed away.

an10.107:6.2.pli: ye ca micchāvimuttipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti te cassa niddhotā honti;
an10.107:6.2.eng: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong freedom are washed away.

an10.107:6.3.pli: sammāvimuttipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti.
an10.107:6.3.eng: And because of right freedom, many skillful qualities are fully developed.

an10.107:6.4.pli: Idaṃ kho taṃ, bhikkhave, ariyaṃ dhovanaṃ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati, yaṃ dhovanaṃ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccantī”ti.
an10.107:6.4.eng: This is the noble washing that leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. Relying on this washing, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things.”
